cluster_classes.class_description: Narrative works that represent the Cinderella fairytale, including the overarching tale and specific literary versions.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The familiar Cinderella fairytale and Perrault’s 1697 literary version of that story.

members.entity_description: A classic fairytale about a young woman who, with magical assistance and a lost slipper, overcomes hardship and marries a ruler; known in many cultural variants including the Grimm and Perrault versions.
The 1697 Charles Perrault literary version of Cinderella that added several now-iconic narrative elements.

cluster_classes.class_description: Key magical motifs and plot devices that define the Perrault-style Cinderella narrative.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Perrault's version introduced the fairy godmother, the glass slipper, and the stroke of midnight.

members.entity_description: A magical benefactor character who helps Cinderella attend the royal event in Perrault’s version.
The distinctive slipper made of glass that Cinderella loses, enabling her later recognition.
The specific moment when Cinderella’s magical transformation ends in Perrault’s version.

cluster_classes.class_description: Pairs linking an author and their specific canonical version of a well-known story.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Charles Perrault’s 1697 publication established the most familiar version of Cinderella.

members.entity_description: French author whose 1697 publication established the most familiar version of the Cinderella fairytale.
The 1697 Charles Perrault literary version of Cinderella that added several now-iconic narrative elements.

cluster_classes.class_description: Fictional personae who participate in the ancient Greek Rhodopis Cinderella-like narrative.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Rhodopis and the king are the central figures in the ancient Greek Cinderella-like story.

members.entity_description: A young girl in the ancient Greek Cinderella-like story who marries the king after losing a slipper.
The ruler in the ancient Greek Rhodopis Cinderella-like tale who finds her lost slipper and marries her.

cluster_classes.class_description: Core narrative elements associated with the earliest recorded Rhodopis Cinderella-like story, including the story version, its cultural setting, and its key plot object.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The earliest known version of the Cinderella story in ancient Greece featuring a lost slipper.

members.entity_description: The earliest known recorded version of the Cinderella-like narrative, a story of a young girl named Rhodopis in ancient Greece who marries the king after he finds her lost slipper.
Historical Greek civilization where the earliest recorded Cinderella-like story of Rhodopis originated.
Footwear item in the Rhodopis/Cinderella narrative that enables the king to identify and marry the heroine.

args.new_description: Narrative works that represent the Cinderella fairytale tradition, including the overarching tale and specific literary versions such as Perrault's.
args.justification: This class cleanly represents works in the Cinderella story tradition; assigning a shared Class_Group aligns it with related Cinderella classes in this cluster.

args.new_description: Key magical motifs and plot devices that define the Perrault-style Cinderella narrative, including iconic characters, objects, and temporal constraints.
args.justification: This class groups internal elements of the Cinderella narrative; it should share a unifying Class_Group with other Cinderella-related narrative and entity classes.

args.new_description: Pairs linking Charles Perrault and his canonical 1697 version of the Cinderella story as a specific author–work relationship within the Cinderella tradition.
args.justification: The members are specifically Perrault and his Cinderella version, so the label and description should reflect this focus and be grouped with other Cinderella narrative classes.

args.new_description: Fictional characters who participate in the ancient Greek Rhodopis Cinderella-like narrative, including the heroine and the king.
args.justification: This class captures characters from an early Cinderella-like variant; placing it in the same Class_Group connects the Rhodopis tale to the broader Cinderella narrative tradition.

args.new_description: Core narrative elements of the earliest recorded Rhodopis Cinderella-like story, including the story version, its ancient Greek cultural setting, and its key plot object.
args.justification: This class aggregates entities from the Rhodopis Cinderella-like narrative; assigning the shared Class_Group links these early elements with other Cinderella-related classes.
